body.u: 14 November 2005Transcribed by Mark Steven VarelaMILAM: My name is Dr. Ron Milam with Texas Tech University, Vietnam Center. Today I am interviewing Bob Loudermilk. Bob, I’d like to start by asking you to tell me what your MOS (Military Occupational Specialty) and responsibility was on November 14th, 1965.
My MOS was 1981, which is rotary-wing aviator assigned to Delta Company, 229th Assault Helicopter Battalion of the 1st Cav Division.
And your rank?
I was a captain.
You were a Captain. Where did you get your commission? From what commissioning source?
Commission source was ROTC (Reserve Officer Training Corps) Marshall College, in 1958.
1958. When did you become a helicopter pilot? What time—
I went through fixed-wing transition first, in the qualification course. Then in July of 1960, I went to helicopter school.
July of ’60?
Yeah.
So you’d been flying helicopters for about four years, before the 11th Air Assault was formed at Benning.
That’s true.
When did you go to Benning?
I went to the 11th Air Assault in ’63.
1963. So you were there from essentially the beginning, the experimentation with airmobile concept?

I got there right after Air Assault One, if you’re familiar with that program. Air Assault One had been run—small version of the airmobile division was tested. The full division testing was Air Assault II, and I was there for the training up to and including that. Sometime after that it was finished.
Between 1960, July of ’60, when you become a helicopter pilot and you’re going to Benning—you had flown, were you on flying duty that whole time?
Yes. I spent 14th months of that time in Korea.
In Korea.
Flying both fixed wing and rotary wing aircraft, then I spent about a year and a half at Fort Devens, Massachusetts. From there I went to helicopter school, from Fort Devens.
When you were in Korea, what were you flying? You said fixed wing and rotary. What rotary wing were you flying there?
H-13s. So, did you—when you went to Benning, did you immediately start flying the UH-1s?
No. When I went to Benning, I volunteered to fly Mohawks.
Mohawks.
OV-1.
Yeah.
I spent two years, better than two years, flying an armed Mohawk in support of helicopter operations.
I see. When did you first get in a UH-1?
First time I got in a UH-1 was in Vietnam.
Really?
I got one hour and thirty-minute transition from my H-13 days to my UH-1 days and I was not only a Huey pilot, but I was also made aircraft commander at the same stroke.
I see.
We were in a hurt for people and qualified people, so we produced them pretty quickly over there.
Tell me a little about your training with the 11th Air Assault once the airmobile concept was up and running. What did you do there?

I'm not sure the timing of this, but the notice came out that the 11th Air Assault would be transitioning into the 1st Cav Division with no other assignments at that time, but everyone kind of had a feeling what was going to happen. At the same time, they did away with the armed Mohawk. We had a surveillance company of Mohawks, same airframe, different capabilities electronically in the unit and they kept that. Made a platoon private.
Could you explain the Mohawk a little bit? Is this an observation—armed observation helicopter?
This is a fixed wing airplane.
I'm sorry, a fixed wing. Okay. But armed?

Armed. The version that we used because of the assault support for the helicopters had to be armed. So they didn’t come out of the factory that way, but they were remanufactured and pods hung on the wings and gun sights placed in front of the pilot, and all the switches and associated things that went with it.
So your role in training at Benning with what becomes the 1st Air Cav was different than the role you would be with them in combat?

It was different, and it was the same. Different because I was flying a completely different aircraft in a completely different environment. When we flew Mohawks, the fleet of helicopters would fly by and we would escort them by flying around them. We were so much faster than they were that we couldn’t just slow down and fly beside them. So we would fly around them in a wagon wheel type support in route to the objective and as they began to slow for the assault, we would go ahead of them and fire into the designated landing areas on both sides, front and back and try to keep down the heads of anybody that might be in there.
Did you ever do that in combat?
In the helicopter, yes.
I mean in the Mohawk?
In the Mohawk, no.
Did the army ever do that in the Mohawk?
The army used the iron Mohawk from way of Phu Bai, in an out of country mission that I was not privy to know what it was. I was not in the unit, so I wasn’t privy to know.

I'm learning something from this interview, I mean not that I don’t learn something from every interview, but I was not familiar with that concept. In Vietnam, in the beginning days with Ia Drang being one of those beginning times, the gunships, as I understand it were essentially Hueys and the Cobra comes in later. But it was Huey gunships here in the beginning. Did they fly? Was that the role the that the gunships flew in escort?

I flew the B Models and later what they called the C Model 540. It had a stiffer rotor system and different engines, basically the same airframe. The B Model was a little slower than the Delta Model UH-1, that was the troop-carrying aircraft. We were slower because we just didn’t have the engine power and we didn’t have the rotor size; our rotor was shorter and not as wide spanwise as theirs. Also, we were loaded to the hilt when we took off the ground. We were at max gross weight every time we took off. When you put fuel in it, four souls, pilot, crew-chief, gunner, and co-pilot and then put ammunition and the armament kit that hung on the sides of the helicopters, which were pneumatic and hydraulic and electric and all the things that went with that, and all the ammunition for both rockets and machine guns. Many times, to get those aircraft out of the revetments where they were parked, they were parked between sandbag revetments to protect them from mortar fire in the evenings and all. To get them out of there, the crew-chief and gunner had to get out. We picked the airplane up and hover it back and slowly turn it in the direction we were going to take off and lightly touch the skids to the ground enough for the crew-chief and the gunner to hop on and then just like eggshells, get that airplane off the ground. Especially on real hot days or high altitudes, it was just loaded, and it was loaded to the max gross weight of the aircraft. The UH-1Ds were a little more powerful, they didn’t always have—although a lot of times they were loaded too, but not always did they have a full load of troops on. Maybe they only had half a load of fuel because of the amount of troops that they had. But anyway, they were faster than we were. But we could—or they would allow us to keep up with them in flight. There wasn’t any ringing around the formation, no way. (Chuckles) That’s up for Cobras to do maybe, but not us. We sat right out here on their wing. The whole formation being stacked back here as they went. We sat out right here, and when they started to slow down, we wouldn’t go any faster, we were going as fast as we could go then. But when they slowed down their relative speed, put us ahead of them, going into the LZ (Landing Zone).
When did you get notified, that you were going to Vietnam?
When President Johnson came to Fort Benning and made his stadium speech. That day he had notified the 1st Cav Division that they were going to southeast Asia.
You already had orders with the unit, you knew what you were doing in the unit and it was just a matter of when you left?

Actually, at that time I was assigned to the remaining platoon of the surveillance Mohawks, as a fixed wing aviator and I was going to go with what’s called the ASTA (Aerial Surveillance and Target Acquisition) platoon of the Cav, part of the 11th General Support Aviation Company and go to Vietnam in the 1st Cav as a Mohawk driver.
That’s what you were on? So when they said the 1st Air Cav was being sent to ‘Nam, you knew you were going in the role of being a Mohawk pilot.
That’s right.
How did they take the Mohawks to Vietnam? Did they take them on the ships?
They went on ships, on carriers.
Just like the choppers and everything?
They went through the Suez Canal, on the Boxer.
How about you? How’d you go?
(Chuckles) I went on the Darby, out of Charleston, South Carolina.
You’re planning on getting there and jumping into your Mohawk?

Well, I planned on going over on the Boxer. However, after I loaded all of my equipment, the 1st Cav’s ASTA Platoon, all of my personal gear in there CONEX container that was going to be shipped with the platoon, they decided that they were short helicopter pilots, so that anyone filling a fixed-wing job that had a helicopter MOS would henceforth become a helicopter pilot only and to find themselves a helicopter job in the 1st Cav.
Go find yourself? Or they’ll find it for you?
No, you find it yourself. I'm sure they would’ve found something for you, but the best deal was to go find the job you wanted, rather than to have them tell you where to go which is always better.
If the Mohawks—and the Mohawks ended up going to Vietnam, the planes themselves.
Oh yes, sure.
What percentage of fixed-wing pilots, that you knew, were also rotary qualified?

Probably sixty percent, maybe more. At that time for an officer to get into aviation program, you went through fixed-wing training first. That’s just the way you did it in the army. In ’58, ’59, when I went to school, the ponderance of the army aircraft were small, light, fixed-wing airplanes. Helicopters were coming but H-13 type coming, not anything real big except maybe H-21s and H-19s. That changed when the warrant officer program took off. They all went to helicopter school first. We never got many warrant officers in the Mohawks. Most of the ones we had were commissioned officers, so they were I think almost eighty, ninety percent of those were dual rated. But some of the ones that we had assigned had been to Vietnam before and were exempt from going back because of the policy by the army at that time, so they brought the pilots from Vietnam that had been there originally in ’63 and ’64, back to Fort Benning, to fly in the 11th Air Assault because of their expertise in combat operations. As soon as the gong went up to go to Vietnam, those pilots were all exempted from going back to Vietnam, so they had to fill cockpits.
And those pilots in Vietnam, supporting mostly the US advisory effort period ’62, ’63, and ’64, were they flying Hueys?

Some flew Hueys. Some flew H-21s. There was a mix of aircraft in country, as units that did most of the support of the ARVN (Army of the Republic of Vietnam) troops. We didn’t have any US troops over there then at the time, in big numbers anyway.
Right. So—

In my company, for instance Delta 229, as we landed to shore in Qui Nhon, from the Darby, to my recollection, there was one member of that company as a commissioned officer trained helicopter driver, that had trained with the 11th Air Assault Division.
Only one?
In rotary-wing airplanes. We had five of us that had been Mohawk drivers that were in my company.
I see, my goodness.
The rest of them came from all over the world, some Huey qualified, some not.
So the training that the infantry soldiers got at Benning, to learn how to get in and out, do all those things, most of that was with pilots who would not then accompany them into combat.
In most cases, that’s true.
Interesting.

The 11th Air Assault, in my understanding was that the helicopters were being flown with a pilot and a crew-chief sitting in the co-pilot seat. No gunner and crew-chief in the back with weapons because there wasn’t anything to for them to fire at, it was a training exercise. Only later when they got to Vietnam, were they armed with M60s and placed in the back. The gunners actually came to us from the infantry.
Right, there was no gunner MOS at the beginning, as I understand it.
No.

Okay, let’s talk about—you come into Qui Nhon and you know you’re going to be a chopper pilot and then you transfer to An Khe and we build this base at An Khe. When do you start flying for real in these Hueys? Right away?

No, about two weeks after we got there. The main reason was that I spent one night at An Khe, in a pup-tent like everybody else did, shifting sandbags from one side of the pup-tent to the other side because that’s where the sniper was supposed to have been, now he’s on this side, so we put the sandbags over here. The next day the company commander detailed me to go back to Qui Nhon to pick up all of our company equipment that was being offloaded from the ships, and get it all together and he would send people by truck or helicopter back there to Qui Nhon and then they would bring the equipment back to An Khe. We had nothing. We had what we carried over there and that was the company. So all of our mess equipment, all of the company administrative equipment, trucks, vehicles, water tankers, all that stuff was still on the ships. So I became the go-getter for that type of equipment and all of the vehicles were identified by plaques that they put on there, of what unit they belonged to, so that supposedly you could get your own unit vehicles when they got off the ship.
When you started training on the Hueys, since you had limited experience, you flew solo for a while? I mean, no troops obviously, you got out and learned to fly that thing?

No, I went out with the instructor pilot in the Huey, UH-1B for my training flight. It consisted of an hour and a half. We did all the basic stuff. He gave me credit for a lot of knowledge I'm not sure I had.
(Laughs)

But anyway, at the end of that period I asked him, “What was the difference between this helicopter that we just flew, and a fully on, ready to go helicopter on a mission.” He said, “The one difference is we took the machine gun barrels out for this flight, but the flight that you go on next, we’ll put the machine gun barrels in that same aircraft and that’s the one you fly on in the first mission.” So I had a fully loaded, fully armed flyable, viable gunship to train in for an hour and a half and then it was mine.
Before November 14th, 1965, there were a few other operations I understand. One called “Silver Bayonet”; I believe over in Happy Valley. Did you participate in that?
Yes.

And you were flying guns? The gunship?(Editor’s Note: Interviewee nods head)From an infantry standpoint, I understand they had relatively low incidents of contact on the ground. As a gunner, did you have—were you shot at on “Silver Bayonet”?
Yes, we lost one helicopter to enemy fire near an LZ. On the first or second day of the work over by Happy Valley.
I see.
That—they didn’t make a mistake; they had the inopportune chance to fly right over a machine gun that was sitting there waiting for them.
.50 cal? Or—
It was a large caliber.
Large caliber, larger than—it wasn’t an AK?

It wasn’t an AK-47. One round came up and shot the co-pilot’s pedals off during this raking of a helicopter and shot out the field control, the helicopter was uncontrollable as far as flying is concerned so they hit hard and the co-pilot was cut up in the face, got out and came back to us as a viable pilot. The pilot was hurt, back was hurt substantially. He was medevac’d and we didn’t see him again.
I see.
I have seen him since, he’s still doing fine but he’s crippled.
I see. Was that the most significant operation that you were involved before Ia Drang?
That was it. That was where we found the most action. We went into a lot of scenarios where we were looking for something to get into, but each one came up pretty much dry.

Let me understand a little bit—as an old infantry solider, I know how valuable gun support is, but I don’t know enough about what it was like back in 1965 when it’s kind of in its infancy. You were going to support the introduction of slicks into an LZ. You were going to support it in terms of security.
Yes.
Were you also tasked with responsibility for supplying close end gun support to troops on the ground, at their call?
Emergency only.
Emergency only, okay.
Even during LZ X-Ray, we were never tasked to deliver fire in direct support of the engagement.
Right.

Helicopters that did that were ARA, aerial rocket artillery. They weren’t called, they had a forward observer who would direct their fire. We had no one except a very excited company clerk on the phone, down on the mic down there or the battalion commander maybe, but someone who is imminently involved in getting orders and actions taken care of, that would be trying to tell us where we could fire and where we couldn’t fire.
Sure, sure.
We were trained in air deliver of weapons, but not in support of our own troops on the ground.
Right, tactical errors—
Because we didn’t know where they were.

Tactical errors support, as I understand it studying the history of the war, comes later when the Cobra gunships are put in where troops can pop smoke and direct it and essentially talk to the chopper pilots from the ground, but not in these earlier days.

Well, the popping smoke was another problem because sometimes the Vietnamese would monitor the broadcast and they say, “Pop red smoke” and we’ll fire twenty-five meters in front of it. Well, the Vietnamese would throw the North Vietnamese, or the Viet Cong would have smoke from wherever they got it, they’d pop it so the guy would say, “Well, I guess it’s here.” And we have—it had actually happened the ARA, in one instance that I'm aware of, fired on our own troops because someone popped the wrong smoke or identified the wrong smoke. So that was not a good way to—
Right. It became a matter of smoke out, please identify, and you’d carry three or four colors.

That’s right. The direction in front of that smoke- if he’s coming from a different direction, say to my front and he doesn’t know where your front is, it’s hard to tell where those rounds are going to end up and you don’t want to be on that receiving end of your own fire.

This is very interesting because this is the guns—I’ve always personally wondered how the gun support worked at Ia Drang and I think I’m about and find out. Okay, let’s talk about your role on the 14th, November 14th. When did you get the order to move out? And in what order were you going to be in support that morning?

Prior to the 14th, we had made several different forays relative to that area in the Pleiku, Plei Me area. I believe, in my recollection it was after the Plei Me siege, where the camp was under siege and they set up an ambush for the relief forces coming down the road, the Vietnamese. The North Vietnamese set up for them. The camp was really a ruse to get them down there. They set up an ambush on the road, so they wanted to kill a lot of them in the main forest and they did. That’s when the cav, I believe, started looking in that area. They knew they had some large forces in that area, they did not know where. We started leap frogging from An Khe, we went to Pleiku, Holloway, Holloway Field and set up a sort of base camp there with our tents. Then we set up a refueling point, an arming point at a place called Plantation, which is farther to the west, getting over to no-man’s land. As a big—it was a Plantation because it was a little air strip that supported a Michelin rubber plantation and we encamped right beside the rubber trees, so we knew what it was. That was a fairly large forward base. From there, after Plei Me was secured, we moved the refueling and rearming point to Plei Me, the little triangular camp right down near the border. From there, we would go in and logger there, sit on the ground there for a while until everybody got ready to go. Then, when the troops were ready, either the troops came out of Plei Me or they came from Pleiku—I'm not sure then because that was the slicks, and we weren’t involved in that particular administrative part of the move, but as soon as we left from Plei Me, joined the flight—
In air? When troops are coming out, you come in with them?

In the air, as well as I can remember, we joined them in the air. We had our radios on and when they were coming, we took off our flight of four—two from each two sections, one on one side of the formation, one on the side and it was a fairly large formation, maybe twelve, I forgot the exact number. I'm sure our aviation historians can bring me up to date, but I'm not aware of it. But anyway, however many it was, it was a good size fleet. We had four gunships, usually we’d only use two maybe on a small flight, but this time we had four. We escorted them out until they started descending, in which they started slowing down and then we were able to go ahead of them. We were fortunate because that was the only LZ in my twelve o’clock position. It was right at the base of this big hill, I'm from West Virginia so it was just a hill, not a mastiff, but it’s called a massif.
Chu Pong?
Chu Pong.
Yes.

And it went all the way back into the dividing between the two countries. Anyway, it was the only area that looked suitable to me for a landing, so—a lot of times you did recon where you’re going to do it. You go on a set of map coordinates, and the maps weren’t all that great either. The flight leader of the slicks said, “My twelve o’clock, thousand meters, do you see it? Do you see it? Do you see it? Okay, you got it.” So we go ahead of them and fire. ARA had gotten there before us, as the armed helicopters. They had already had the coordinates, so they fired, so we could see where they were firing and then it was a piece of cake for us to find it after they had already found it for us.
They’re lighting up the LZ or just beyond it?

As far as I know, what I saw anyway, a rocket is an area munition. It is not a directly fire like they have now, that go down and find people some place and go in it. When you fire a rocket, you just say goodbye to it because it goes out and when you see it go out, it does this kind of thing.(Editor’s note: Interviewee expresses with hand gestures.)So it’s an area weapon, when you fire two of them, one could hit over here, and one can hit over here.
Is it HE (High Explosive) or is it “Willie Pete”?
Depending on the head that you roll onto it when you—
What were they using, do you know?

Some of them had—most of them were just HE. Later, we got some heads that had an extend fuse on the front of them, had a tip extender that stuck out this far. When they hit, they went off and spread it all laterally, shrapnel, but the ones we had initially were just the rounded bullet like heads and when they hit, I'm sure they penetrated and made a big hole and blasted anything that was there. You could be maybe fifteen yards from it, and you’d get an earache and maybe that’s all if you were laying down.
The idea was to prepare the edges of the LZ in case—most likely that would be where the enemy was located, not firing on the LZ itself because there’s no point in that.
The LZs in most cases over there were grass, if you fired HE onto grass, it set it on fire, and you don’t want helicopters landing on the fire, that doesn’t go good at all.
Of course, you don’t want—
It makes for a lot of mad helicopter pilots, I know that.
Right, and you don’t want holes in the ground that infantry troops have to get over and everything else.

But LZ X-Ray was not only lit up, by lit up I mean fired on and smoke coming from the sides of LZ X-Ray, you could see the termite mounts. It was clear enough, they had reeds down there. They were so tall they looked like big grass, tall grass, but it was suitable for a small helicopter operation.
Did you fly in the first lifts? Were you escorting the first lifts in?
Yeah, yeah.
As I understand it, the first couple of lifts in, there was no enemy fire.

Absolutely nothing. We monitored—we had two radio sets; two different type of radios sets. One was between the helicopters, on a UHF (Ultra High Frequency) frequency. We had an FM (Frequency Modulation) frequency that was tuned in to the ground commander, just so we could hear what was going on, because we wanted to know.
Sure.

We heard nothing but normal administrative chatter, you know, get here, get there, dig in here, set this up. Nothing about any fire, nobody getting excited about anything, we had done that, and they had done that numerous times up to then and then we gone in later and picked them up with no contact. So we expected it to be just another day just like that.
That’s lift one and two or so. You get your choppers in, and then you go back to wait for the next wave?

We made our break around after we’d fired, and we just set up an orbit on both sides of the LZ, on the incoming azimuth until the helicopters had gone in, dropped and picked up. When they pick up our lead gunship, picks up his initial position, flying the wing of the lead ship, we escorted them out of the LZ, because coming out is as bad as going in. You can kill all the good guys coming in and left all the bad guys at the far end. When you came out, they could’ve rigged the helicopter. We were there in case they got fire.
So there was no fire either coming in or going out on the first couple of lifts.
No fire. None reported.
Then, about lifts three or four, somewhere in there, things changed. Tell me about that.

Yeah. The second trip in, as well as I know, the only reason it was more than one trip in because the first trip couldn’t get all the guys in, so he wanted the whole battalion in there and I don’t blame him. Even though—because he didn’t know what he was going to have to face. So we went back and got more. Rearmed and refueled and came back in, expected to set them in and you know, another lazy day of circling around the sky. Everything was fine, nothing going on. We went back, rearmed and refueled for the last—we thought would be the last load of the day. I think it might’ve been on the way back, before I changed frequencies, I heard something about sniper fire. I looked at the co-pilot and said, “Did I hear that right?” He said, “Yes. I was likely to take fire in there.” I said, “Well, it’s probably isolated, but we’ll find out when we come back. Time we took off again, they had obviously taken fire, a lot of it and it was getting heavier. They’d called artillery in and when we took off from Plei Me, which is, I would guess ten or twelve miles from LZ X-Ray, you could see the plume of artillery smoke which wasn’t there earlier and it certainly didn’t come from us going up to three or four thousand feet and getting higher. Which meant, to the people that observed our artillery, that there is a lot of stuff falling on the ground there and for a reason. That reason was because they were getting hit.
In monitoring the frequency, did it then become—well, let me ask you this question, what then became your role? Troops on the ground engaged in big fire fights—
Our role became stay with the slicks and don’t fire,
Stay with the slicks, don’t fire and then it would become a matter of the slicks are going to be going in and out of resupply missions, and evacuations of the wounded for the next two days.

Well, I can only speak for the rest of that day, and I’ll explain that in a minute. When we took the slicks in for the—I believe it was the third time, it could’ve been the second time, maybe the third, things got confusing that day. Thinking back forty years is tough right now. Anyway, on the time when the ground commander said, “Don’t come in.” I mean we had the troops on board, we had the supplies for him on board, we had the slicks. He said, “Don’t come in, it’s too hot right now. Go someplace else and orbit until I let you know.” We took off and when out a little bit and orbited. Meanwhile, I saw some Air Force airplanes come in, and possibly some Navy airplanes, I don’t know, the jets were so fast you couldn’t tell what they were. They were ours anyways. They were bombing in close proximity to that LZ, something I hadn’t seen before. Usually, they got back in the headquarters and did their bombing in the Viet Cong headquarters or something, but not up on the front lines. This was pretty close to what I had to consider as the perimeter, knowing they hadn’t gone too far. We’d heard that there was a platoon on reconnaissance. We didn’t know where they were. I didn’t know they were back. All we knew is that they had sent a platoon someplace and it was cut off and they couldn’t get them back in. That was weighing on my mind, about where to fire. Plus, the fact that from where we were, I couldn’t see anything happening. We were far enough away, so to get out of the way from the Air Force and arterially that was still coming, they had to coordinate the artillery coming in and pull it off long enough for the lift to get in so they wouldn’t knock down their own helicopters. That’s when I saw two A-1Es. Two A1s, I did not know if they were Es or not, whether they were Air Force or Navy, I'm not sure now. I believe they were Air Force that had been called in and I looked at them with awe because if it wasn’t for the change in doctrine in the cav, I would’ve been flying a fixed-wing airplane possibly with armament on it. Anyway, I saw them peel off, by that, make their run. One behind the other. The first one dropped ordinates and pulled up. The second one, I looked up and there he came, he never pulled up. He didn’t drop anything that I saw, and I was a mile away. He went straight into the ground. I believe it was just north of LZ X-Ray, maybe a half a mile. I'm not positive with that, but I think recollection wise, that might’ve been where he was. It just exploded. All the ordinates went in the fuel and it just burned right there on the spot. It went in about a fifty-degree glide, which is a normal ordinate delivery glide. Forty-five would be like this, and fifty is about this. So very steep glide and then just straight into the ground, for reasons that I don’t know. I didn’t see anybody shoot at him, but they could have. I was dumbfounded, I couldn’t believe it, what I’d just seen. That’s not supposed to happen. We were away from there, so I told the slick that I was going over to recon, I went over and flew around one time at about three-hundred feet, and a helicopter came underneath me, a slick helicopter. One that had just departed over there in LZ and it come in and landed in a little—barley big enough for a little helicopter to get in, a little clearing underneath and the crew chief and the gunner got out of the helicopter and ran three-hundred yards. That’s the closest they can get with the helicopter. Three-hundred yards to the wreckage to see if there are any survivors. Meanwhile, I pulled up around and said, “My goodness, I’ve never seen anybody do anything like that.” I came back around again and then I saw, about a hundred and fifty yards or two hundred yards from the helicopter, people in black uniforms.
Black uniforms?

Black uniforms. I didn’t notice if they had hats on or not. Usually you see them—yeah, you see them with—I wasn’t used to seeing them up that close, but they were moving to what looked like encircling movement on the helicopter who was just sitting out there, the pilot and co-pilot were sitting the helicopter running while the crew chief and gunner and they were running back. I was afraid they were going to get around them and shoot at them. They looked like they were trying to encircle a helicopter and keep them from going back out again. So I fired at them.
You fired at the pajamas?
I fired the machine guns.
At the black pajamas?
We had four M60s machine guns on the side of the helicopter and the crew chief and the gunner each had their own M60.
You operate the machine guns on your pods from your seat?

From a sight in front of the aircraft commander on the left side or the pilot can operate them in the stone position, where they’re just aiming straight ahead on the helicopter, so he has to move the helicopter around to get the guns move around, but I can take them and move them up some elevation and then straight down and to the side. This one will move off to the side like this, this one will come over a little ways and then it quits firing because you don’t want it firing out here where you’re not looking. You evidently want it to fire over here but it won’t do it, so it quits, or you can do it the other way and this one quits and it fires out here. I was firing at them at an angle because I was seeing them, and they ran behind trees. Big enough trees, it didn’t take much to hide one of them. So I went out and did a real quick turn and I came back the other way, I said “I’ll get them this time, from the rear.” They were smart enough to run around the other side of the tree. So I put a lot of lead in trees but I wasn’t—I stopped them from moving, they were now concerned about themselves rather than that helicopter, which was a good thing and he’s still sitting over there, waiting on the crew chief and gunner to come back.
Can you talk to him?
I had no communications with him whatsoever.
You had no frequency to him, okay.

I called him a couple of times, “Helicopter on the ground, what’s your ID?” No return, I don’t know. I never found out. But anyway, I know somebody— I know the boys knew who it was, but the gun people never found out. So then I made two more passes, slow with the guns pointed straight down. The crew chief and gunner both standing on the skids with M60s firing straight down and there’s no way to hide behind a tree straight down. So we did a pretty good job on them. I don’t know what part of the Viet—the PAVN we called them then, People’s Army of North Vietnam. I don’t know what part they were or whether they were Vietnam irregulars or what.
It sounds like they were—but they were in black you said?
They were in black tops and bottoms.
Chances are they were VC (Viet Cong) regiment.
But they never fired at me, if they did, I didn’t see them and I didn’t hear the round go by. They didn’t hit the helicopter.
Did the men get back from the—
Yes, they did. To finish the story, they came back clamoring onboard the helicopter and he got what we called “didi mao”. He got out of there.
The A-1E pilot was killed?
As far as we know, the pilot was killed.
Yeah.

There were rumors that there was a parachute, but as an instant observer, I watched him all the way down from six-thousand feet and there was no chute, that I saw. I would’ve seen it. There was no ejection seat in that aircraft, I don’t believe. I believe for a chute, he would have had to throw the canopy off, unstrap, stand up, and push himself out of the fixed-wing airplane. At those speeds, he couldn’t have gone out.
So you’ve had a gunship incident that maybe kept those guys alive, that are in the chopper waiting for their crew to come back.
Well, it could be that they never would’ve made their way all the way there if we had not been there that day.
Whatever it is, you were—that’s what you did.
I felt better about it.
Sure, you did, absolutely. Now, we’re now in mid-afternoon, tell me about the rest of your day.

The rest of the day was back to Plei Me. Rearm, refuel, back out again. Each time we went in, the slicks were going in, not as a unit now, as eight to ten slicks. They were going in as one, two. So it was hard to escort—we tried to escort each one. By the time we got around, he was coming out and another one was trying—they’d say, “That’s not a good way to go in, go in another way.” So they’d come over and try to come in this way. They really made it tough for us because we didn’t know where he was going to go. So anyway, we just kind of loosened up a little bit but there wasn’t anything we could do anyway. We could give him moral support.

Colonel Moore was talking to the slicks and telling them how to come in, and all you could do was to follow the slick in and give him the support. He was talking to the slick as a slick and you guys were the slick support.

He didn’t even know we were up there; I think. I mean, he was only interested in his slick, his people or the supplies and getting his wounded out. He didn’t care about some gunship sitting out there, whether we supported or not. We were there for moral support for the helicopter crew that were going in. Whether they thought about us or not, that’s not here nor there.
You worked LZ X-Ray in support of these slicks, one at a time coming in, for the rest of that day?
Past dark.
Past dark. Then you went where?

Then we went to Plei Me and refueled, and some of those were rather long flights because the spread out of the individual helicopters going in. There weren’t as many of them toward the end, they didn’t have as many go back, but the ones that did go back were spread out pretty far, so it took longer. So each time we were burning up fuel. Anyway, we go back to Plei Me and refuel. I know one of our helicopters on the last trip in, as he set the helicopter down at the refueling point, it flamed out. It ran out of gas. Just as he cut the throttle to shut it down to get fuel, it quit. Mine was—I had a couple lights on. You start getting—when you get low on fuel, you’ll get a pump light on that tells you that your down to a certain level and friends, you better be on the ground pretty soon. You know how your gauge is, you know it’s there and you know it’s saying empty, but you can always wish that there is hope, that there’s a little bit more fuel in there. I never ran out of fuel, I sweated it a few times and he sweated it that time. But anyway, it was on the ground when it quit so it wasn’t a big problem, but that’s how drastic it was to get the support out there, at least to get the helicopters out there and do whatever it took to put them to bed for the night out there and get themselves protected.
Did you wait for the calls for the next two days or how?

The next two days—we had a maintenance program in Vietnam, very much like they have in the States. Hundred hours and then you inspect. In Vietnam, they allowed us to fly ten percent over that if it was necessary. When I came back that day, my helicopter was a hundred and twenty-five hours since it’s last inspection. We didn’t put twenty-five that day, we put on—I don’t know, seven or eight-nine hours. But it was above and beyond, I was already pushing the point when I went out that day. I knew it, the maintenance also knew it, he said, “When you bring it back tonight, it’s down. I don’t care what happens.” Of course, he didn’t know about X-Ray. But anyway, he was an administrator at that point. So when I got back, he said “Unh-unh, it’s down.” So I flew it back to Pleiku and they pulled it into the field there at Pleiku. It took a day and a half to pull the inspection and then I was back. Meanwhile, the second day, our boys were doing—my compatriots were doing the same thing in and out. By the time I got back in the air, X-Ray was evacuated. Albany, which was the firebase, was about to be—I think Albany was the firebase, anyway—
Falcon?

Falcon. Falcon was being evacuated. The Chinooks had picked up all the artillery tubes and all the good artillery. All the rounds. I guess I'm not an artilleryman but I'm sure they had some—then they were going to blow the LZ. They did that quite often when they left the LZ where they had a lot of artillery. If they get a bad lot of ammunition, rather than bring it out and take a chance on getting it mixed with good ammunition, they wouldn’t waste a helicopter going in to get bad ammunition, they would blow it after they left. All the revetments where the helicopters were set and all that. Anything that was the garbage dump. Anything that could be possibly used by the enemy for anything, was blown up. I was in the air orbiting when the last ship came out with the engineers. I believe the engineers went in and set all the charges and the timer and then got on the last helicopter. The commander wanted verification that everybody was out. “Is everybody out? Are you sure?” “Yeah, I'm sure there’s nobody down there.” It looked like a small atomic blast went off when Falcon was leveled.
So you spent then—your tour is only three or four months old. Did you spend another eight months there in Vietnam?
Yeah, I was the last of the original sailors that came over on the—not the advanced party, but the sailors that came over on the boats. I was the last one to leave the company, last officer.
I see.
As far as I know, the last person. We had a whole new second team in, when I left there.
How about—was that your only tour there in Vietnam? Or did you spend another one?
No, I went back a year and half later.
With what unit?
The 1st Cav Division.
Oh, you did?
I went back and flew Mohawks!
Oh, you did? So you got to fly your fixed-wings.
I got to go back and fly fixed-wings. It wasn’t the armed ones; I flew surveillance out Phu Bai. I got back just in time for Tet. I got there the day Tet started.
For goodness sake.
I thought it was in commemoration for me, for coming back.
You spend another year then?
I spend another year.
How much more time did you spend in the army?
I spent a total of twenty years; I came back in January of ’69. I got out in ’78. So I got nine more years in.
What was your rank when you came out?
Lieutenant colonel.

Lieutenant colonel. In your second tour, did you experienced—I know there has been nothing of the magnitude, from a unit standpoint, like LZ X-Ray and Albany, like the Ia Drang. But did you experience anything personally, to compare with what you went through at Ia Drang?

Well, I never experienced anything like the troopers went through at Ia Drang. Mine was a support role, I saw what they had to contend with, but I didn’t contend with it because I flew around, and I went back. Then I came back, and I went back. They stayed there and did their job on the ground and did a tremendous job of it. The second tour, it was filled with several things. The A Shau Valley, the 1st Cav in the A Shau Valley was a very deadly time. Against a much heavily armed foe than we had the time. They had anti-aircraft position dug in and they changed them quite often. I got to go over to An Khe—yeah.
Khe Sanh?

Khe Sanh, when the Marines were going through all that they went through there. B-52s had been called in. The 1st Cav at this time was up at LZ Evans, up in the northern I Corps, operating around the Huế area. Up and down the QL1. But An Khe was—I mean Khe Sanh, was liberated supposedly by the 1st Cav. At least when we got there, the cav got there up the road and moved off, got the Marines out of there, then we all walked out of there, the Marines and everybody. But they were using B-52s during the siege. They made a strike and asked for a BDA, a battle damage—bomb damage assessment. Since we had a photographic aircraft, they called us to go up and do a BDA. So I took a mosaic and drew the chart of where I was going to fly. Then went back and flew up and down that mosaic and took verticals and obliques, we called them, of the right and left side of the airplane. It looked like the face of the moon. I don’t know how anybody could’ve survived a B-52 strike. I’ve seen them from afar, and I’ve seen them from fairly close and I’ve seen afterwards. I wouldn’t want to be in the same county with a B-52.

Well Bob, we very much appreciate you allowing us to interview you and for you to go on record with these experiences. We at Texas Tech, know that your interview will be there for a very long time. It will be part of our archives and it will be accessible to historians in the future and that’s very important to us as historians, so we can talk about this terrible time.
Good. I hope your project is successful.
Thank you very much, we appreciate it.(End of interview.)
